In summation then it's basically discussing a model based on biological 
neural nets and a class of topology that supports 'self-sustaining' 
activation. A burst of stimulation can set off these self-sustaining 
states and a further burst can switch them back off. This is because a 
biological neuron can only fire so often, presumably because it has to 
're-charge' or refill its store of neuro-transmitter before it can fire 
again. So if the number of interconnections is high then the neurons 
fire too often, they deplete their neurotransmitter and are unable to 
fire in response to incoming signals, this then leads to the 
self-sustainability coming to an end. If there are too few 
interconnections then the self-sustainabilty never gets going. So there 
is some range of  interconnection proportion that can support the 
self-sustaining activity.

I think recurrent connections have already been shown to provide memory 
in ANN's and in NEAT. Certainly the prey capture domain evolved very 
simple recurrent connections back onto the source neuron that allow the 
agent to remember for a short while where the prey was last seen after 
it had moved outof sensor range.

What this paper is doing is showing that large numbers of biological 
neurons can participate in large scale recurrency and therefore this 
could theoretically be the basis for short term memory in biological brains.

Colin.
